bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Hanson, July 10, 1923

div1.p: Carter writes that he believes control of aegypti mosquitoes in the Bucaramanga-Cucuta area of Colombia may be sufficient to eliminate yellow fever from the entire region.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Hanson, July 10, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Columbia.
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
July 10, 1923.
Dear Doctor Hanson:
div1.p: This is simply to wish you good luck in your work in Colombia.

Even if Bucaramanga (and the Cucuta region?) is simply a part of a
more extensive regional focus, still when such a focus is on its last
legs the control of aegypti at even one point may be sufficient to eli-
minate infection in the whole focus, as work in Panama freed the coast
from Bocas to Santa Marta.

I have carefully, and rather extensively, gone over the evidence
for the Norman settlements on, and trade with, West Africa; I think
I must have examined 30 books and articles, and there is none of any
weight for its existence prior to 1616, when they had trade with the
grain (Malaquette) coast, from which they were later driven by the Portu-
guese. There is about the same evidence for this as there is for St.
Brendan's: Norumbega and the lost Atlantis. No claim was made for it
until 1666 and the evidence they have--the existence of some French
names on the Grain Coast at that time--quite certainly came from their
establishments from 1616-20.
I have a note from Dr. Beato of Habana as follows:

“La Fiebre amarilla en el interior de Colombia. Epidemia de
Cucuta. Fiebres del Magdalena, por el Doctor Luis Cuervo Marquez.
Curazao. 1891.-4- de 380 paginas.”
div1.closer:
Sincerely your friend, H. R. Carter (Per Laura, as Dad
had to leave just after dictating this to keep an appointment. Good
luck from me too--y vaya con Dios!
